    Academic Work Experience

    Doctoral Researcher (2018-present)

    • Project: Investigating neuronal network development of neurodevelopmental disorders and neurodegenerative diseases using multielectrode arrays
    • Supervisors: Dr. Julio Martinez-Trujillo & Dr. Lyle Muller

    Graduate Teaching Assistant (2019-2023)

    • 2023: Introduction to Psychology as a Social Science (Dr. Shelley Cross-Mellor)
    • 2022-2023: Human Physiology (Dr. Pierre Thibeault)
    • 2021-2022: Human Physiology (Dr. Christine Bell)
    • 2020-2021: Mammalian Physiology (Professor Tom Stavkraky)
    • 2019: Physiology of Senses (Dr. Tutis Villis)

    Research Assistant (2016-2018)

    • Project: Primer design and optimizing gene knockdown using qPCR in drosophila transgenic RNAi lines
    • Supervisor: Dr. Jamie Kramer

    Publications

    • Hyperexcitability in human MECP2 null neuronal networks manifests as calcium-dependent reverberating super bursts

      Pradeepan, K. S. et al. Hyperexcitability in human MECP2 null neuronal networks manifests as calcium-dependent reverberating super bursts. Biorxiv (2023).

    • Wide spectrum of neuronal and network phenotypes in human stem cell-derived excitatory neurons with Rett syndrome-associated MECP2 mutations

      Mok, R. S. F. et al. Wide spectrum of neuronal and network phenotypes in human stem cell-derived excitatory neurons with Rett syndrome-associated MECP2 mutations. Transl Psychiatry 12, 1–16 (2022).

    • Distinct neural codes in primate hippocampus and lateral prefrontal cortex during associative learning in virtual environments

      Corrigan, B. W. et al. Distinct neural codes in primate hippocampus and lateral prefrontal cortex during associative learning in virtual environments. Neuron 110, 2155-2169.e4 (2022).

    • Multielectrode arrays for functional phenotyping of neurons from induced pluripotent stem cell models of neurodevelopmental disorders

      McCready, F. P., Gordillo-Sampedro, S., Pradeepan, K., Martinez-Trujillo, J. & Ellis, J. Multielectrode Arrays for Functional Phenotyping of Neurons from Induced Pluripotent Stem Cell Models of Neurodevelopmental Disorders. Biology (Basel) 11, 316 (2022).
